title: How to Make Elderberry Soup

methods.name: Cooking Simple Elderberry Soup with Stone Fruit

steps.headline: Place the juices, sugar, cloves, and cinnamon into a pot.
steps.description: Set a large pot on the stove and pour 4 ⁄4 cups (1,000 ml) of elderberry juice into it along with 1 squirt of lemon juice. Then, add 1/2 cup (100 g) of sugar, 4 cloves, and a 2-in (5 cm) stick of cinnamon and stir until the sugar is dissolved. Turn the burner to high so it comes to a boil. Use a non-aluminum pot, since elderberry juice reacts to aluminum. You can find elderberry juice at most natural grocers or health food stores.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup for 10 minutes over low heat.
steps.description: Turn the burner down to medium so the soup bubbles gently as it cooks. Stir the soup frequently as it cooks to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot. Leave the lid off of the pot so some of the liquid evaporates. This will thicken the soup a little.

steps.headline: Cut 10 damson plums and 4 pears into slices.
steps.description: Cut the plums in half and remove the pits. Then peel the pears and cut them in half. Remove the cores and slice each pear into 1/2 in (1.3 cm) pieces. If you can't find damson plums, use 5 black or red plums instead. Choose Bosc or Anjou pears so they keep their shape in the soup. If you'll be blending the soup, you could use Bartlett.

steps.headline: Add the fruit and simmer it for 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Stir the sliced plums and pears into the hot elderberry soup. Let the soup continue to simmer over low heat until the fruit softens. Then use tongs to remove the cloves and cinnamon stick. If you prefer smooth soup, use an immersion blender to blend the plums and pears into the elderberry soup.

steps.headline: Serve the simple elderberry soup.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and ladle the hot soup into serving bowls. Serve the soup immediately with sour cream on the side. If you prefer, you can chill the soup and serve it cold. Refrigerate the leftover elderberry soup in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Measure the elderberries and remove the stems.
steps.description: Get out 3 cups (435 g) of fresh elderberries or 1 cup (160 g) of dried elderberries. Place them in a fine mesh strainer and rinse them with water. Then pick off and discard the stems.

steps.headline: Bring the water and elderberries to a boil.
steps.description: Put the prepared elderberries into a large stockpot and pour in 6 cups (1,400 ml) of water. Put the lid on the pot and turn the burner to high heat. You should see steam escape from under the lid once the water begins to boil. Ensure that the pot isn't made of aluminum or the metal will react with the elderberries.

steps.headline: Lower the heat and simmer the covered elderberries for 45 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner down to low heat so the water bubbles gently. Keep the lid on the pot and simmer the elderberries until they become soft. Dried elderberries will probably need the full 45 minutes to become soft while fresh elderberries may be done after 40 minutes.

steps.headline: Blend the elderberries.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and use an immersion blender to combine the elderberries with the water until the elderberries are completely smooth. If you don't have an immersion blender, you can transfer the elderberries to a blender or large food processor.

steps.headline: Strain the elderberry mixture through a fine mesh strainer.
steps.description: Place a fine mesh strainer over a large bowl and push the elderberry mixture through it using the back of a spoon. The strainer will remove most of the seeds.

steps.headline: Transfer the berries back to the pot and add 3/4 cup (150 g) of sugar.
steps.description: Pour the strained elderberries back into the stockpot and turn the burner to medium heat. Stir in the sugar until it dissolves. Keep the elderberries warm while you make the thickening cornstarch slurry.

steps.headline: Mix the cornstarch with water and whisk it into the elderberries.
steps.description: Put 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) (8 g) of cornstarch into a small bowl and stir in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of cold water. Stir until the cornstarch dissolves and then whisk it into the elderberries.

steps.headline: Bring the elderberry soup to a boil and stir in the apples and lemon zest.
steps.description: Whisk the soup frequently as it begins to bubble and thicken. Then peel and dice 2 cups (235 g) of tart apples. Stir in the diced apples along with 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) (6 g) of grated lemon zest. Tart apples include Pink Lady apples, Granny Smith apples, and Honeycrisp apples.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Adjust the burner so the soup is bubbling gently. Leave the lid off and simmer the soup until it thickens a little. Stir the soup occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot.

steps.headline: Chill the soup for 3 to 4 hours before serving.
steps.description: Pour the soup into smaller airtight storage containers and put them in the refrigerator to cool completely. When you're ready to serve the soup, ladle it into serving bowls and offer crumbled gingersnap cookies and sour cream on the side. To cool the soup down even faster, place the containers of soup into an ice bath before you refrigerate them. Refrigerate the soup for up to 3 to 4 days.
